abstracts.cdata!:
This is the Implementation Completion
            Report (ICR) for the Rural Development Investment Program
            (RDIP) in Colombia. The project's main objectives were
            to: (i) increase the incomes of about 280,000 poor farmers
            and fishermen; (ii) improve living standards of the rural
            communities through provision of basic infrastructure; (iii)
            promote grassroots involvement of rural communities in the
            identification of investment needs and subsequent
            maintenance; and (iv)strengthen DRI's capabilities to
            prepare, appraise and supervise projects. The RDIP's
            outcome is judged satisfactory. The Bank's overall
            performance was satisfactory. The overall performance of the
            Government (Borrower) and Fondo DRI (Implementing Agency) is
            judged deficient. Some key lessons of the RDIP are as
            follows: 1) a participatory and decentralized operation
            which is to finance many small projects in a large number of
            localities, cannot work if it is overburdened by
            bureaucratic, centralized rules which characterize normal
            operations of the Colombian Government and World Bank; 2) a
            flexible, open design is needed for centrally managed
            programs targeted to local; 3) the process of designing this
            type of operation should be highly participatory; 4) a
            simple monitoring and control system should be in place from
            the start in this type of operation in order to rapidly
            identify and correct problems; 5) it is advisable to
            separate monitoring and evaluation functions.
